The U.S. Department of Defense's Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) is developing the Carbon Expeditionary for Energy Resilience and Stabilization project, which aims to store electricity to charge batteries using CO2 sources without resorting to standard energy sources.

As the authors of the portal noteМilitary Аerospace, in the Pentagon, the contractors were aimed at creating a device that should be portable and recharging, capable of generating fuel electricity and catching the CO2 exhaust gases for their regeneration, the Army Informs.

Representatives of the United States Department of Defense, in cooperation with private companies, intend to create technology that will make it possible to produce fuel from carbon dioxide sources to provide electricity and charge batteries used on the battlefield. The project is called ExCURSion (Abbreviation, not "excursion" from English!) — Expeditionary Carbon Utilization for Energy Resilience and Stabilization.

The terms of reference from DARPA emphasize that batteries and fossil fuels dominate modern technologies for portable energy storage and its use by military expeditionary forces.

Although batteries can be charged from any voltage source, most chargers have so low energy density that they cannot be used in military missions that require small size, weight and power consumption. In this case, fossil fuel based on hydrocarbons has a much higher energy density, but it is quite expensive.

Darpa researchers are looking for an opportunity to generate fuel from carbon dioxide sources, as they say, in places to provide high energy density and simplify logistics. According to them, the capture, storage and conversion of carbon dioxide into energy -accumulating fuel will create a completely closed system that can replenish its stocks on its own.

Such an action scheme could simplify recharging and operating batteries during military missions.

So far, engineers working on specialized projects face two problems:

  • the production of liquid fuels from CO2 is at least 30 times slower than the recharging of lithium batteries;
  • The capture and storage of CO2 from exhaust gases is complicated by the trade-off between the performance and stability of the materials used.

Darpa plans to solve these problems by attracting scientists working in the field of battery technology. For example, it is known that the University of Boston developed material for carbon dioxide in closed spaces, such as submarines, underground bins and manned spacecraft.

Companies such as ExxonMobil and the Batttel Memorial Institute also work in the field of carbon dioxide capture and storage, so they can also be involved in the Excursion.
